subsections.title: Success Criteria
points: Explain the meaning of the term pollution.
Describe the causes and effects of different types of pollution.

subsections.title: Definition of Environmental Issues
subsections.content: Environmental issues refer to problems with the planet’s systems (soil, water, and air) caused by human interference.

subsections.title: Definition of Pollution
subsections.content: Pollution is the process of destroying the quality and purity of water, air, and land, making the environment unsafe for living.

subsections.title: Causes of Air Pollution
points: Deforestation or destruction of vegetation cover
Emission of Chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) gases from equipment like refrigerators and air conditioners
Radiation from nuclear testing or accidents
Emission of poisonous gases from car exhausts and industrial fumes

subsections.title: Causes of Water Pollution
points: Industrial effluents discharged into water bodies
Dumping of chemicals and dead organisms into water

subsections.title: Causes of Land Pollution
points: Poor waste disposal on land surface
Dumping of metals and chemicals on land

subsections.title: Causes of Noise Pollution
subsections.content: Caused by excessive sound that interferes with human and animal life.

subsections.title: Causes of Light Pollution
points: Sports and entertainment lights at night

subsections.title: Effects of Air Pollution
points: Skin cancer due to ozone layer depletion
Disturbed hydrological cycle due to high temperatures
Melting of icebergs leading to ocean flooding

subsections.title: Effects of Water Pollution
points: Spread of waterborne diseases such as cholera
Scarcity of clean and portable water

subsections.title: Effects of Land Pollution
points: Shortage of land for cultivation due to land degradation

subsections.title: Effects of Light Pollution
points: Disturbs people living near nightclubs or airports
Affects astronomical observations by making stars invisible

subsections.title: Effects of Radioactive Pollution
points: Health problems such as cancer, infertility, blindness, and birth defects

subsections.title: Ways of Controlling Pollution
points: Use of clean and renewable energy sources
Enacting and enforcing environmental protection laws
Imposing penalties on violators of environmental policies
Conducting civic education campaigns on proper waste disposal

subsections.title: Success Criteria
points: Explain the meaning of the term desertification.

subsections.title: Definition of Desertification
subsections.content: Desertification is the steady process by which land is degraded to produce desert conditions. It is also defined as the process of turning good and fertile land into barren and unproductive land.

subsections.title: Natural Causes of Desertification
points: Rain shadow effect of high mountains – the windward side receives rainfall while the leeward side remains dry (e.g. Chikwawa and Nsanje near Mulanje Mountain).
Existence of cold ocean currents – these reduce the chances of precipitation.
Continentality – coastal areas receive rainfall while the interior becomes dry.
Anticyclones – descending dry air leads to dry conditions.
Very high temperature and high rates of evapotranspiration.

subsections.title: Human Causes of Desertification
points: Over-cultivation – continuous use of land depletes soil nutrients.
Opening up new farms (shifting cultivation) which causes deforestation.
Overgrazing destroys natural vegetation, exposing soil to erosion.

subsections.title: Effects of Desertification
points: Very poor crop production due to loss of fertile soil.
Poverty as a result of reduced crop yields.
Flooding due to lack of vegetation cover to absorb rainwater.
Depletion of water resources as rivers and streams dry up.

subsections.title: Ways of Controlling Desertification
points: Using alternative sources of energy such as hydroelectricity to reduce tree cutting.
Conducting environmental awareness campaigns and civic education on environmental conservation.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Maps are symbolic representations of the Earth's surface used to show geographical features.
points: They help us locate places, measure distances, and understand terrain.

subsections.title: Basic Elements of a Map
subsections.content: Essential features that make maps readable.
points: Title – tells what the map shows.
Scale – represents the ratio of map distance to real distance.
Compass rose – shows direction (N, E, S, W).

subsections.title: Types of Maps
points: Political – shows countries, cities, and boundaries.
Thematic – focuses on specific themes like population or climate.

subsections.title: Map Reading Techniques
subsections.content: Skills required to understand and interpret maps.
points: Contour lines – show elevation and shape of the land.
Measuring distances using the map scale.
